title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — In a game where the final score suggested a team victory, the truth was written in the singular, spectacular performance of one man. Allen Iverson didn’t just beat the Orlando Magic; he authored a masterpiece, pouring in a career-high 40 points to will the Philadelphia 76ers to a 100-91 triumph.

From the opening tip, this was the Iverson Show. The electric rookie was a blur of crossover dribbles and fearless drives into the heart of the Orlando defense. He operated with a breathtaking audacity, slicing through the lane and finishing with acrobatic layups over taller defenders. When the Magic defense sagged off, Iverson punished them from the perimeter, his shooting stroke as cold-blooded as his drives were relentless.

While Orlando’s Penny Hardaway fought valiantly to keep pace, contributing 22 points and 8 assists, and Rony Seikaly controlled the glass with 16 rebounds, they were merely supporting actors in Iverson’s coming-out party. The 76ers’ victory was not a product of a perfectly balanced attack, but of one phenomenal force of nature. Derrick Coleman’s 14 points and 11 boards provided a crucial interior counterpoint, but the engine of this win was undeniably Iverson.

On this night, the Spectrum was a cathedral for a new basketball deity. Every explosive move, every impossible basket, was a declaration. Allen Iverson didn't just score 40 points; he announced his arrival to the league with a performance that was both historic and prophetic, a sign of the legendary, score-at-will career that was to come. The final buzzer signaled more than a win; it was the dawn of the Iverson era in Philadelphia.
